title: AI Fluency Certificate — RAG Pack (Institutional Design Corpus)
text:
AI Fluency Certificate — RAG Pack (Institutional Design Corpus) Date: 2025-12-26 Owner: Jim Wentworth (CITL, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign) What this is This folder contains the canonical “design authority” documents for building and maintaining the Generative AI Fluency Certificate .
It is intended to be uploaded into a ChatGPT Project (or similar RAG workspace) to: keep the certificate’s conceptual framework stable, make design decisions legible to collaborators, preserve rationale and provenance over time, support AI-assisted drafting without losing intent, guide Canvas + DesignPLUS implementation choices. How to use (recommended workflow) Start with the Canonical Overview (01_...). Treat it as the source of truth for the learning arc and module boundaries. When making changes, record why in Design Rationale & Decisions (03_...). Keep it short, decision-focused. For any new page/activity, follow the Canvas + DesignPLUS Implementation Guide (06_...) and validate against the Example page (07_...). Use Tool Documentation References (05_...) whenever you need to verify platform capabilities. Use Branding & Accessibility Guardrails (04_...) when styling pages, selecting colors, and creating visuals. Design norm (internal) We document “behind-the-scenes” work. Drafts are allowed; rationale must remain visible. If AI assists in drafting, we preserve: intent, constraints, tradeoffs, and what the human decided. File index 01_Certificate_Canonical_Overview.md 02_Design_Process_Transparency_Provenance.md 03_Design_Rationale_and_Decisions.md 04_UIUC_Branding_and_Accessibility_Guardrails.md 05_Tool_Documentation_References.md 06_Canvas_DesignPLUS_Implementation_Guide.md 07_Example_Canvas_Page_DesignPLUS.html 08_Content_and_Prompt_Templates.md

title: Generative AI Fluency Certificate
text: Generative AI Fluency Certificate Canonical Overview & Conceptual Framework (RAG Anchor) Executive Summary The Generative AI Fluency Certificate is a practical, skills-based program designed to equip lifelong learners with foundational knowledge and strategic capabilities required to responsibly and effectively use generative AI tools in academic, creative, and workplace contexts. Rather than focusing on specific tools or isolated techniques, the certificate emphasizes durable understanding, sound judgment, and intentional design—skills that remain relevant as technologies evolve. The certificate is organized around a four-module learning arc that reflects an increasingly sophisticated relationship with generative AI. Participants begin by building accurate mental models of how generative AI systems function and where they fail. They then learn how to collaborate with AI systems in ways that expand thinking without outsourcing judgment. From there, the program shifts toward practical reality: designing AI interactions that are consistent, reusable, and accountable in real work contexts. The final module extends these principles beyond text to multimodal systems, addressing opportunities and risks in image, audio, and video generation. Throughout the program, emphasis is placed on human agency, ethical responsibility, and transparency. Participants are encouraged to view AI not as an authority or decision-maker, but as a probabilistic system whose value depends on how it is framed, constrained, and documented. Particular attention is given to responsibilities introduced when AI-assisted processes are reused or shared, including disclosure, privacy, and error propagation. Program Purpose Help participants move from surface-level experimentation with generative AI to intentional, responsible, discipline-aware use across teaching, learning, research, creative practice, and workplace contexts. Guiding Principles Generative AI systems are probabilistic, not authoritative. Human judgment remains central at every stage of AI-assisted work. AI is most valuable when it expands thinking, not when it replaces it. Reuse and sharing introduce ethical and practical responsibility. Documentation and transparency support accountability and trust. Tools will change; principles and practices should endure. The Learning Arc Understanding — Accurate mental models of how GenAI works and fails Collaborating — Iterative inquiry that expands thinking without outsourcing judgment Designing — Consistent, reusable AI interactions that hold up under reuse and scrutiny Expanding — Applying the same critical framework to multimodal systems Modules are intentionally sequenced and are not designed to be interchangeable. Module 1: What GenAI Is — and What It Isn’t Purpose Establish foundational mental models for how generative AI works and where it falls short. Participants examine the mechanisms that drive generative models, recognize constraints, and develop realistic expectations. Learning Emphasis Demystifying generative AI Distinguishing capability from appearance Recognizing constraints and risks (hallucinations, bias, context limits) Boundary This module does not focus on effective use ; it focuses on accurate understanding. Module 2: Collaborative Iteration with GenAI Purpose Shift from passively receiving outputs to actively engaging AI as a collaborator in inquiry and idea development. The emphasis is on shaping conversations to support human thinking rather than delegating decisions. Learning Emphasis Inquiry over output Expansion of cognitive bandwidth Retaining human judgment and authority Includes (by design) Lightweight, conversational personalization (tone, perspective, questioning style) to improve collaboration within a session . Boundary Personalization here is ephemeral and conversation-specific. This module does not create reusable workflows, templates, or persistent system behavior. Module 3: Designing Consistent AI Interactions Purpose Move from exploratory use to intentionally designed interactions that support consistency, reuse, and accountability. Participants learn to shape AI behavior proactively rather than fixing outputs after the fact, with attention to downstream impact. Learning Emphasis Interaction design over prompt cleverness Reliability and reproducibility rather than “better answers” Responsibility introduced by reuse and sharing Key Topics What “consistency” means in probabilistic systems Prompt patterns and reusable templates Grounding AI with participant materials (documents, examples, curated references) Selecting appropriate levels of structure (prompt → template → agent/workflow) Documentation practices that support reuse and auditability Ethical risks introduced by persistence, reuse, and context collapse Boundary This module is about designed interactions others (or future-you) may rely on—not momentary personalization. Module 4: Engaging with Multimodal GenAI Purpose Expand beyond text to image, audio, and video generation/analysis. Participants apply the same critical frameworks while developing literacy for new affordances and risks introduced by multimodal systems. Learning Emphasis Transfer of principles across modalities Critical evaluation of synthetic media Accessibility, ethics, and media literacy Boundary This module does not assume multimodal outputs are inherently better; it focuses on appropriate, critical, and ethical use. Program Elements (Completion & Structure) Electives Participants complete two AI-related electives (events, workshops, or trainings) aligned with professional goals. Electives deepen learning but do not replace the core arc. Elective criteria (recommended): Active engagement with AI concepts/tools/ethics (not passive exposure) Clear connection to at least one core module Evidence of completion (documentation or reflection) Learning Reflection Project (Learning Journal / Portfolio) Participants maintain a learning journal that captures developing fluency with generative AI. Each module contributes artifacts (prompt examples, AI-assisted drafts, reflections, multimodal creations) documenting growth in skill and awareness. Time expectation: roughly 6–10 hours across the certificate. Most effort should be hands-on practice; reflections can be intentionally brief and used as anchors. Total Time Designed for approximately 15–20 total hours (guided instruction + experimentation + learning artifact creation).

title: Design Process, Transparency, and Provenance
text:
Design Process, Transparency, and Provenance Internal working norms (institutional visibility) Why this exists The certificate is built using iterative design work that may include AI-assisted drafting. To keep the work defensible, reusable, and collaboratively maintainable, we treat process transparency as a core design norm. What “behind-the-scenes documentation” means (internal) We preserve enough context for future collaborators (and future-us) to answer: What was the intent? What constraints were we designing under? What tradeoffs were considered? What decision did we make, and why? What should not be inferred (boundaries / non-goals)? This is not a demand for polished memos. Draft notes are acceptable. Legibility beats perfection. AI use in certificate creation (norms) AI may assist with: synthesis, drafting, reframing, checklists, template generation, and formatting support.
AI should not: silently erase debate, remove uncertainty, or “optimize” away intentional boundaries. When AI is used, capture: purpose of the AI use (brainstorm, rewrite, structure, etc.) key constraints given to the AI what the human accepted, modified, or rejected anything that remains uncertain Provenance artifacts we maintain (recommended set) Canonical overview (stable “source of truth”) Design rationale notes (decisions + why) Canvas/DesignPLUS implementation conventions Branding/accessibility guardrails Tool documentation references (official docs links) Non-goals (to prevent drift) Platform certification or vendor training “Best prompts” mastery as the primary outcome ML engineering or coding specialization (unless elective) Treating AI as an authority in academic decisions

title: Design Rationale & Decisions
text:
Design Rationale & Decisions Decision log (summarized, decision-focused) Use this document to record the “why” behind major design choices.
  Keep entries short. Prefer bullets. Include tradeoffs when relevant. Current major decisions Module arc : Understanding → Collaborating → Designing → Expanding Rationale: increases participant responsibility and transfer across contexts. Module 3 framing : “Designing Consistent AI Interactions” (not “Customizing tools”) Rationale: emphasizes interaction design, reuse, accountability, and documentation—beyond cosmetic or tool-specific tweaks. Personalization placement : included in Module 2 as lightweight, conversational tuning Rationale: supports collaboration and inquiry without implying persistence or workflow reuse. Documentation emphasis (internal) : certificate creation itself follows transparent, documented workflows Rationale: institutional defensibility; avoids “black box” creation; enables shared maintenance. Open questions / future decisions Elective governance: how strict should “acceptable elective” criteria be? Canvas packaging: IMSCC vs. direct page build vs. hybrid DesignPLUS conventions: standard set of wrappers, components, and iframe patterns Branding: which UIUC brand assets are approved for Canvas pages (logos, marks, photography)

title: University of Illinois Branding & Accessibility Guardrails
text: University of Illinois Branding & Accessibility Guardrails Institutional design constraints (for certificate materials) Canonical UIUC brand guidance (official) Brand Guidelines (home): https://brand.illinois.edu/ Visual Identity — Color: https://brand.illinois.edu/visual-identity/color Visual Identity — Typography: https://brand.illinois.edu/visual-identity/typography Visual Identity — Logo: https://brand.illinois.edu/visual-identity/logo Resources / Downloads: https://brand.illinois.edu/resources/downloads UIUC Brand CDN (colors reference): https://cdn.brand.illinois.edu/colors.html How we apply UIUC branding in this certificate (project norms) Illinois branding should be recognizable but not overpower instructional clarity . Use UIUC primary colors purposefully and accessibly; avoid overusing secondary palettes. Prefer consistent typography and spacing rules across pages to reduce cognitive load. Clearly mark what is official certificate content vs. external vendor examples. Accessibility guardrails (non-negotiable) Ensure adequate color contrast for text and key UI elements. Provide alt text for images and meaningful labels for buttons/interactive elements. Avoid “color-only” meaning (use icons/labels in addition to color). Keep layouts responsive for mobile and varied screen sizes. AI-generated visuals and institutional representation AI-generated images/text used in official materials must be reviewed for: brand consistency accessibility clarity and appropriateness for the audience Avoid synthetic imagery that could imply official endorsements or misrepresent the university. Notes for Canvas + DesignPLUS Canvas rendering and DesignPLUS components may constrain typography and layout. The implementation guide (06_...) defines project defaults that align with UIUC branding where feasible.

title: Canvas + DesignPLUS Implementation Guide
text: Canvas + DesignPLUS Implementation Guide Conventions for building certificate pages Goals Pages render reliably in Canvas. Pages are compatible with DesignPLUS (Cidi Labs) conventions. Interactives that require embeds use responsive iframe wrappers. Code remains maintainable (avoid fragile editor behaviors). DesignPLUS wrapper (dp-wrapper) Some DesignPLUS elements require a wrapper on the page to display properly. If a page is missing the wrapper, components may break. Reference: https://support.cidilabs.com/knowledgebase/how-do-i-add-the-design-tools-wrapper-to-my-page Project convention: all custom HTML pages include a dp-wrapper at the top-level when using DesignPLUS patterns. Iframe responsiveness (DesignPLUS wrappers) DesignPLUS uses wrapper classes for responsive iframes. If the wrapper is removed, styles may not function. Reference: https://support.cidilabs.com/knowledgebase/why-are-my-iframes-not-displaying-properly Common wrapper classes (per Cidi Labs guidance): kl_iframe_responsive_scale kl_iframe_fill_width Project convention: all embeds use the wrapper pattern shown in the Example Canvas Page (07_...). Editing guidance (avoid breaking DesignPLUS styles) Using Canvas RCE tooling can sometimes break DesignPLUS styling. Reference: https://support.cidilabs.com/knowledgebase/why-do-some-designplus-features-break-using-the-canvas-toolbar-and-rich-content-editor Project convention: treat the Example Page as the “known-good” pattern; minimize manual edits that reflow HTML structure. Page components (recommended baseline) H2 page title short intro paragraph “Why this matters” bullets key concepts knowledge check / activity embed areas (iframes) only where needed Implementation checklist (for every page) Uses consistent header hierarchy (H2, H3, H4) Uses dp-wrapper when DesignPLUS components are present Uses iframe wrappers for embeds; includes title attribute Includes alt text / labels as needed Avoids over-nesting and unnecessary inline styles

title: Content & Prompt Templates
AI Fluency Certificate — Frequently Asked Questions (Living Document)
text: AI Fluency Certificate — Frequently Asked Questions (Living Document) RAG Add-on / Institutional Reference Status: Living document (iterative) Purpose: Provide a stable FAQ reference that supports certificate clarity, reduces ad-hoc explanations, and gives AI systems an authoritative place to ground answers to common questions. Canonical Source This FAQ content is currently published at: 🔗 https://jimwentworth.github.io/AI-Fluency/cert_faqs.html This Markdown file is intended to become the canonical, version-controlled source that can: be used for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), be adapted for Canvas pages or websites, and evolve over time as questions recur or policies change. How this FAQ is used (design intent) Audience: prospective participants, current participants, facilitators, administrators Function: clarification, expectation-setting, and reduction of ambiguity Non-function: marketing copy, policy enforcement, or tool documentation When used by AI systems, this FAQ should: answer common questions consistently, defer to official policy or documentation when appropriate, avoid speculative or tool-specific claims unless explicitly stated. Core FAQ Categories (initial structure) Certificate Scope & Purpose What is the AI Fluency Certificate? Who is the certificate designed for? What does “AI fluency” mean in this context? What is the certificate not intended to do? Program Structure & Time Commitment How long does the certificate take to complete? What are the four core modules? Are modules required to be completed in order? Can modules be taken asynchronously or in person? Learning Journal / Reflection Project What is the learning journal? What kinds of artifacts should be included? How detailed do reflections need to be? What tools can be used to host the journal? Electives What counts as an acceptable elective? Can external workshops or courses be used? How do I document elective completion? Tools & Technology Which AI tools are used in the certificate? Do I need paid accounts? Are there institutionally supported tools? How is privacy handled? Assessment & Completion How do I earn the certificate? Are quizzes graded? What happens if I don’t pass a quiz the first time? How is completion verified? Ethics, Integrity, and Responsible Use Is AI use allowed in assignments? How should AI use be disclosed? What counts as inappropriate AI use? How does the certificate address bias or misinformation? Maintenance Notes (internal) This FAQ should be reviewed periodically to: remove outdated tool references, clarify recurring points of confusion, align language with the Canonical Overview. Substantive changes should be noted in the Design Rationale & Decisions log. When answers depend on institutional policy, link out rather than paraphrase. Next Steps Migrate content from the current HTML FAQ into this Markdown file. Mark answers that are provisional or policy-dependent. Align terminology with the Canonical Overview (Module names, learning arc language). Use this document as a grounding source in the ChatGPT Project.
